{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485761,"name":"","username":"Mara1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/4af34b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T17:21:35.256Z","cooked":"

Hello. We would like to use the REV 2m distance sensor for an FRC robot. It is far away from the rio. Is there a way of connecting it to a NEO spark flex or spark max or daisy chaining it into the CAN Bus? Thanks.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-17T17:21:35.256Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":240,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":1245.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":482301,"topic_slug":"rev-2m-distance-sensor-wiring","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44530,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/rev-2m-distance-sensor-wiring/482301/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3485772,"name":"Andrew McBride","username":"AndrewMcb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T17:33:41.957Z","cooked":"

The REV 2m distance sensor has an I2C connection. You will need an I2C port on some device to connect it. Make sure you don’t connect it to the RoboRIO onboard I2C either, recommended port is the MXP I2C port on the roborio instead as per Known Issues — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

My personal recommendation would be to use a different companies Time of Flight distance sensor, either LaserCAN or CANrange, both of which can connect directly onto the CAN bus.

Good luck!

Looks like you are not going to use I2C but I still feel like I should mention this. Last year my team used a color sensor that connects to the I2C on the Rio to detect if we had a note or not. Problem was if that the color sensor saw no color it would return a null value, which due to the way I2C work would cause the rio to hang waiting for a value that would never come. I would definitely recommend not using I2C if possible like the last post said.

Might be off-topic, but:
Please don’t use the REV 2m distance sensor!

We used it to detect notes in intake last year. It caused our intake to fail for 3 out of 9 qualifications. The i2c communication is unstable, and once it disconnects it won’t re-connect until you restart your robot. Not to mention that the sensor itself is not reliable either.

These sensors are far better choices:

AndrewMcb:

LaserCAN or CANrange

We never got that sensor to work right with the Roborio. (It works great in ftc with the control hub. ) we’ve had great experiences with the LaserCan. (Which gives you much better wiring options)
